Title: The Oxford Critical Guide to Homer's Iliad (Oxford Critical Guides)
Author: Jonathan L. Ready
My Review:
It isn't what i was expecting. I wanted to understand the illiad and its background, but this book only explains the plot and an inspid poetics analysis of each chapter/book of the Illiad. It's like reading a summary of the story, which was not what i was looking for. I expected to find an explanation of the Iliad idea of virtue, of the hero, of their cosmology, of their mythology, etc.

The book summary one can find in wikipedia is richer than the one of this book.

Title: Mastery
Author: Robert Greene
My Review:
I like Robert's writing style. He uses his knowledge of classical history and evolution to create metaphors so that the reader may understand his ideas to a greater degree. I love that.

I read about 30% of the book, since it is in that part that Robert talks about mastery in the context of University/Work/etc., which is not useful for me in this moment, for I'm in the prior stage: Figuring out what subject to master. And this book was very helpful in helping me figure it out.
I would have liked if he had picked different geniuses as examples of mastery, for I think some of the ones he picked are relevant and insightful, but I think many historical polymaths were better examples. Also, I think he had an opportunity to discuss mastery in a broader sense, and include subjects such as learning as a lifestyle, routines, mindsets, and other things that history's polymaths' lives can help us with.

Title: Memories, Dreams, Reflections: An Autobiography
Author: C.G. Jung
My Review:
Tough I disagree with Carl Jung, it was an rich and interesting reading.

Jung wrote extensively about his infancy, yet little about his adulthood, and it left me with a feeling of missing something, as if he didn't want to talk that much about his adult life, and that's why I give it 3 stars, because i was expecting to know more about his life, and I was met by an impoverishment of detail in events and details since the book started covering his adulthood period. Events shrank, and it feels like everything that regards his adulthood happened very quickly and vaguely, for it seems like he didn't want to talk about his adulthood. Ironically, he was very open about his fantasies and dreams, yet not about his life and study (at least in his biography)

Title: Ikigai: The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life
Author: Héctor  García
My Review:
If I had to describe this book, I would do it by calling it "A magazine", and as every magazine, youre not going to get knowledge or reflection from it, but entertainment.

Summary: A group of friends goes to one Japan's most logevous islands and draws conclusions on how to live a life as long as the one of the island's inhabitants based on the personal interviews they performed. The conclusion is nonsense, since not even the island's inhabitants know why they live so long, and credit incorrect things, like "smiling" and "working on something you love". Also, the authors study the island culture and habits, and try to find what makes these people live for even more than 100 years, and end up in common sense conclusions: walk daily, eat until you're 80% full and be happy.
If you came here looking to "find your ikigai", this book isn't for you either. It talks about it without having understood it in its depths.

I could have taken more value out of my time if I would have read a couple of Wikipedia entries about "ikigai" and its related subject.

Title: The Knight in Rusty Armor
Author: Robert    Fisher
My Review: if youre considering reading this book, please dont, you will thank me later. it isnt deep, it is superficial, it doesnt invite you to reflect, but tells you a self help cliche discourse. if you are looking for fiction that may uplift you, consider anything but this.
